author: Jozko Mrkvicka
title: How to Make a Difference: The Art of Food Donation
text: Donating food is a wonderful way to contribute to your community and help those in need. The process is simple and can make a significant impact on the lives of individuals facing food insecurity. Start by gathering non-perishable items from your pantry, such as canned goods, rice, pasta, and other staples. Consider organizing a neighborhood food drive to collect donations from your community. Remember, even small contributions can add up to make a big difference.

author: Jozko Mrkvicka
title: Cooking for a Cause: How Your Culinary Skills Can Help Others
text: Explore the intersection of passion for cooking and community service by joining cooking classes for a cause. These workshops not only teach you new culinary skills but also provide an opportunity to give back to the community. Learn to create delicious meals while supporting local food banks and charities. It's a win-win for both food enthusiasts and those in need.

author: Jozko Mrkvicka
title: The Power of Community: Hosting Your Own Food Drive
text: Discover the impact you can make by organizing a food drive in your community. Hosting a food drive is a fantastic way to engage your neighbors and collect essential items for those facing food insecurity. Spread the word through social media, local community centers, and schools to encourage widespread participation. Your efforts, no matter how small, contribute to building a stronger and more supportive community.

title: Sustainable Eating: Reducing Food Waste and Supporting Others

From meal planning to mindful grocery shopping, discover how small changes in your habits can contribute to a more sustainable and compassionate food culture.

author: Jozko Mrkvicka
title: Volunteer Opportunities
text: Get involved in your community by exploring volunteer opportunities related to food donation and hunger relief. Many organizations rely on the support of volunteers to carry out their mission. Whether you have a few hours to spare each week or can participate in special events, your time and effort can make a meaningful difference. Connect with local charities, food banks, and community centers to find volunteer opportunities that align with your interests and schedule.

author: Frodo Baggins
title: Understanding Food Labels
text: Navigate food labels and make informed choices when shopping for groceries. Learn about common terms and symbols on food packaging, including nutritional information, expiration dates, and certifications. Understanding food labels can help you make healthier choices for yourself and your family. Stay informed about the impact of your food choices on your health and the environment by reading and interpreting food labels accurately.

extras.heading: Check the serving size and servings per container
extras.text: The serving size is the amount of food that is typically eaten at one time, and the servings per container is the number of servings in the whole package. The serving size and servings per container can help you compare different products and control your portions. The nutrition facts and the ingredients list are based on one serving, so you need to multiply them by the number of servings you eat to get the total amount of nutrients and calories you consume.

extras.heading: Check the serving size and servings per container
extras.text: The calories and the calories from fat tell you how much energy you get from one serving of food. The calories from fat are a subset of the total calories, and they indicate how much fat is in the food. The general guideline is to choose foods that are low in calories and fat, especially saturated and trans fat, which can raise your cholesterol and increase your risk of heart disease and stroke.

extras.heading: Pay attention to the % Daily Value (%DV)
extras.text: The %DV tells you how much of a nutrient one serving of food provides compared to the recommended daily intake for a 2,000-calorie diet. The %DV can help you evaluate whether a food is high or low in a certain nutrient. The general rule is to choose foods that have 5% or less of the %DV for nutrients you want to limit, such as sodium, cholesterol, and sugar, and 20% or more of the %DV for nutrients you want to get more of, such as fiber, calcium, and iron.

author: Pan Prstenov
title: Reducing Food Waste
text: Discover practical tips for reducing food waste at home and in your community. Explore strategies for proper meal planning, smart shopping, and creative ways to use leftovers. By minimizing food waste, you not only save money but also contribute to environmental sustainability. Learn about the global impact of food waste and how small changes in your habits can make a big difference in preserving resources and minimizing landfill contributions.

extras.heading: Plan your meals and shop smart
extras.text: Planning your meals ahead of time can help you avoid buying more food than you need, and also use up the food you already have. You can use online tools, apps, or calendars to plan your meals, and make a shopping list based on your plan. When shopping, stick to your list and avoid impulse buying. You can also check the expiration dates of the products and buy only what you can consume before they go bad.

extras.heading: Store and preserve your food properly
extras.text: Storing and preserving your food properly can help you extend its shelf life and prevent spoilage. You can use containers, bags, or wraps to seal your food and keep it fresh. You can also use your fridge, freezer, or pantry to store your food at the right temperature and humidity. You can also preserve your food by canning, drying, pickling, or fermenting it. You can find more tips on how to store and preserve your food on websites, such as Save The Food or Love Food Hate Waste.

extras.heading: Use your leftovers and scraps creatively
extras.text: Using your leftovers and scraps creatively can help you reduce food waste and save money. You can use your leftovers to make new dishes, such as soups, salads, sandwiches, or casseroles. You can also use your scraps, such as peels, stems, or bones, to make stocks, sauces, or compost. You can also donate your leftovers or scraps to a food bank, a soup kitchen, or an animal shelter.

author: Janko a Marienka
title: Cooking on a Budget
text: Explore budget-friendly cooking tips and recipes to create delicious and nutritious meals without breaking the bank. Learn how to make the most of affordable ingredients while still enjoying flavorful and satisfying dishes. Discover cost-effective cooking techniques, meal planning strategies, and resources that can help you save money on groceries. Cooking on a budget doesn't mean sacrificing taste or nutrition—find creative ways to make affordable and wholesome meals.

extras.heading: Use seasonal and local produce
extras.text: Seasonal and local fruits and vegetables are usually cheaper, fresher, and more flavorful than imported or out-of-season ones. They also have more nutrients and antioxidants that can benefit your health. You can find seasonal and local produce at farmers’ markets, community-supported agriculture (CSA) programs, or even your own backyard garden.

extras.heading: Plan your meals and shop smart
extras.text: Planning your meals ahead of time can help you avoid food waste, save time, and stick to your budget. You can use online tools, apps, or cookbooks to find recipes that suit your preferences and dietary needs. You can also check the sales and coupons at your local grocery store and plan your meals around them. When shopping, make a list of the ingredients you need and stick to it. Avoid impulse buying and unnecessary items that can increase your spending.

extras.heading: Cook from scratch and use leftovers
extras.text: Cooking from scratch can help you save money, control the quality and quantity of your ingredients, and customize your dishes to your liking. You can also use leftovers to create new meals or snacks. For example, you can turn leftover rice into fried rice, leftover chicken into chicken salad, or leftover bread into bread pudding. You can also freeze leftovers for later use or donate them to a food bank or shelter.

author: Jozko Mrkvicka
title: Local Farmers and Sustainable Eating
text: Discover the benefits of supporting local farmers and incorporating sustainable eating practices into your lifestyle. Learn about the advantages of consuming locally grown produce, supporting farmers' markets, and choosing sustainably sourced foods. Explore the environmental impact of food choices and how small changes in your purchasing habits can contribute to a more sustainable food system. Embrace the connection between your plate and the local community for a healthier and more environmentally conscious approach to eating.
imageAlt: Local Farmers and Sustainable Eating Image

extras.heading: Local food is fresher and more nutritious
extras.text: One of the benefits of eating local food is that it is often very fresh and retains more nutrients than food that travels long distances. Local produce is usually harvested at its peak ripeness, which means it has more flavor and vitamins than produce that is picked unripe and artificially ripened with ethylene gas. Local food also reduces the need for preservatives, additives, and irradiation that are used to extend the shelf life of imported foods. Eating fresh and nutritious food can boost your immune system, prevent chronic diseases, and enhance your well-being.

extras.heading: Local food supports the local economy and community
extras.text: Another benefit of eating local food is that it supports the local economy and community. When you buy food from local farmers and producers, you are keeping money in your region and creating jobs and opportunities for your neighbors. You are also helping to preserve the cultural and culinary diversity of your area, as well as the traditional knowledge and skills of local food producers. Eating local food also fosters social connections and trust, as you can interact with the people who grow and make your food. You can learn more about their farming practices, their stories, and their values, and share your feedback and appreciation with them.

extras.heading: Local food reduces the environmental impact of food production and consumption
extras.text: A third benefit of eating local food is that it reduces the environmental impact of food production and consumption. Local food requires less transportation, packaging, and refrigeration, which means it emits less greenhouse gases and consumes less energy and water. Local food also promotes more sustainable farming methods, such as organic, agroecological, or regenerative agriculture, that protect the soil, water, and biodiversity. Eating local food also helps to prevent food waste, as you can buy only what you need and use it before it spoils. By eating local food, you are contributing to a more sustainable food system that respects the planet and its resources.
